contentrichtext.text: {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox Governor |name=David Marston Clough |image=DavidClough.jpg |alt = |imagesize=230px |caption=David Marston Clough |order= 13th |office= Governor of Minnesota |term_start= January 31, 1895 |term_end= January 2, 1899 |lieutenant= [[Frank A. Day]]<br>[[John L. Gibbs]] |predecessor= [[Knute Nelson]] |successor= [[John Lind (politician)|John Lind]] |birth_date= {{birth date|1846|12|27|mf=y}} |birth_place= [[Lyme, New Hampshire]], U.S. |death_date= {{death date and age|1924|8|28|1846|12|27|mf=y}} |death_place= [[Everett, Washington]] |party= [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |profession= lumberman |spouse= Addie Barton |religion= |footnotes= }} '''David Marston Clough''' (December 27, 1846 – August 28, 1924) was an American politician. He served in the [[Minnesota State Senate]] from January 1887 to January 1893. He served as the state's Lieutenant Governor, January 4, 1893 to January 31, 1895. He was the [[List of Governors of Minnesota|13th]] [[Governor of Minnesota]] from January 31, 1895 to January 2, 1899. He was a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]. Born in 1846 in [[Lyme, New Hampshire]], the fourth of fourteen children of New England farmers who resettled near the [[Rum River]], David Clough helped his family eke out a scanty living from the land by raising crops and cutting timber. His boyhood experiences would serve him well as both an entrepreneur and public servant in a state where agriculture and lumber dominated the economy. Clough's first business venture, a logging operation he founded at 20, lifted him from poverty and launched him on a path toward wealth and political prominence. He moved to [[Minneapolis]] in 1872 and was elected to the city council eleven years later and then to the [[Minnesota Senate]]. From the senate, he advanced to the office of [[Lieutenant Governor of Minnesota|lieutenant governor]] under Republican [[Knute Nelson]], whose election to the [[U.S. Senate]] moved Clough into the governor's office. Clough's first administration was notable for the ratification of significant amendments to the [[Minnesota Constitution|state constitution]], including those establishing the [[Minnesota Board of Pardons]], withdrawing the right of aliens to vote, and authorizing municipalities to frame "home rule" charters. During his second term, narrowly won in 1896, the legislature raised taxes on several private industries and enacted [[Child labor laws in the United States|child-labor laws]]. In 1900 the redoubtable railroad magnate [[James J. Hill]] urged Clough to establish a lumber operation near [[Puget Sound]]. Until his death at age 78, the logger-turned-[[lumber baron]] lived in [[Everett, Washington]], where he championed the interests of the mill owners against their employees' unionization efforts. ==References== *[http://www.mnhs.org/people/governors/gov/gov_15.htm Biographical information] and his [http://www.mnhs.org/library/findaids/gov027.xml gubernatorial records] are available for research use at the [http://www.mnhs.org Minnesota Historical Society.] *[http://www.leg.state.mn.us/legdb/fulldetail.asp?ID=11736 Minnesota Legislators Past and Present] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box |before=[[Gideon S. Ives]] |title=[[List of Lieutenant Governors of Minnesota|Lieutenant Governor of Minnesota]] |years=1893–1895 |after=[[Frank A. Day]] }} {{succession box|title=[[List of Governors of Minnesota|Governor of Minnesota]]|years=1895–1899|before=[[Knute Nelson]]|after=[[John Lind (politician)|John Lind]]}} {{s-end}} {{Governors of Minnesota}} {{MNLieutenantGovernors}} {{Authority control|VIAF=25915286}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Clough, David | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American politician | DATE OF BIRTH = December 27, 1846 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Lyme, New Hampshire]], U.S. | DATE OF DEATH = August 28, 1924 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Everett, Washington]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clough, David}} [[Category:1846 births]] [[Category:1924 deaths]] [[Category:People from Grafton County, New Hampshire]] [[Category:American manufacturing businesspeople]] [[Category:Governors of Minnesota]] [[Category:Lieutenant Governors of Minnesota]] [[Category:Minnesota State Senators]] [[Category:Minnesota Republicans]] [[Category:Businesspeople in timber]]
